Now that it was a thrift store, it was time to get back to feeding her friends and family. So Joann put a hot dog stand out in front of her old restaurant, launching J’s Hot Diggity Dogs.

Joann says it is a “joy to come to work” because she loves people and slinging hot dogs – specifically she says get one with chili, mustard and onion.

Tuesday, October 24, 2023

Kelli Boehle misses her son Nik – but she is also inspired by his short life. When Nik was 17 he was diagnosed with a rare type of cancer. He battled his disease for four hard years, but in the battle he also demonstrated uncommon kindness and generosity.

Nik was blessed with a Make-A-Wish family vacation where his entire family could enjoy Hawaii together and for just a little while, pretend like everything was alright. Many of his peers he met during treatment weren’t as fortunate – having aged out of the Make-A-Wish program. So Nik asked his mom to find a way to make dreams come true for young adults like him, after he was gone.

Flash forward a few years and that’s exactly what Kelli is doing to honor her son’s memory. She built Nik’s Wish – a non-profit that provides blessings for terminally ill young adults between the ages of 18-24. They’ve sent families on vacations, gifted gaming computers, provided celebrity meet and greets, concert tickets and much more.

It’s been 11 years since Nik passed away – but his family is keeping their promise to him, having granted over 300 wishes across more than 30 states.

Monday, October 23, 2023

Did you know that Crayola Crayons is a subsidiary of Hallmark? So it makes sense that the card kings would expand to flowers. Crayola Flowers is selling colorful flower bouquets that you order online to ship around the country.

But Crayola Flowers is much more than a way to capitalize on guys who waited too late to get an anniversary gift. Crayola Flowers is being marketed to non-profits as a fundraising tool – where they can get up to 50% of the sales funneled right into their charity!

Bouquets are priced from $49 to $150 and are shipped directly from farms to customers – with proceeds going to the selected charity. What a beautiful way to spread color, love and hope!

Friday, October 20, 2023

Three generations of one family are currently enrolled at Carthage College in Kenosha, WI. Sisters Samantha and Mia have a dorm room together as they work on their undergrad degrees. Their mom Amy is a graphic designer who enrolled to get her Masters and convinced her mom Christy (Grandmother to Samantha and Mia) to get her Masters as well.

Of course, the youngest of the family have literally grown up on Carthage College’s campus. Their mom has worked there for 20 years. Amy says her daughters drop by her office on campus pretty frequently … for money to go to Starbucks.

And their grandmother Christy is having so much fun being back in school, she’s talking about going for her Ph. D when she’s in her 80s.

Thursday, October 19, 2023

A marathon is a really long distance to run. Honestly, it’s a long drive in traffic. Courtney Rich was on her last mile of a marathon in Salt Lake City, Utah and her body was shutting down on her. But that’s when her 10 year old daughter hopped over a barrier to help.

With her words of support, Avery held her mom’s hand and ran the last mile side by side – in her crocks and jeans – to get Courtney across the finish line.

Think of the people God puts in your life – maybe a daughter, spouse or best friend – that were there to run beside you in life’s big challenges – and give God thanks for them today!

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by Runner’s World (@runnersworldmag)

Wednesday, October 18, 2023

Warrick Dunn is a legend – and not just on the football field. The former NFL running back has devoted his life to making a difference for single moms in the South. Warrick Dunn Charities, Habitat for Humanity and Catholic High School in Baton Rouge – where Dunn graduated himself – just handed the keys to a brand new home to a single mom and her daughter. That’s impressive on its own – but to make it even more spectacular – that house was the 218th home Dunn has helped give away!

Oh – and those homes? Fully furnished. When Dominique and Miracle entered their new Baton Rouge house, they found sheets on the beds, a TV in the living room and food in the fridge. Dunn wants to make sure the future of Louisiana is founded on stable homes for families.

In fact, this Louisiana super star did some major work for SELA after Hurricane Katrina – challenging his NFL peers to give and raised over $5 million to rebuild in 2005. That kind of love makes it easy to forgive him for playing for both the Bucs and the falcons during his pro career!

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by Warrick Dunn (@warrickdunn)

Tuesday, October 17, 2023

Summer is a busy time for Best Cleaners – a dry cleaning shop in Middletown, CT. Not just because their clients have suits and dresses that need to be cleaned and pressed, but it is turtle migration season – and their shop is smack in the middle of the path from the turtles’ spawning pond and the banks of the Connecticut River.

Every employee and customer knows that from May to September, you are going to be recruited to help turtles safely cross the street to the river bank. In fact, helping the tiny turtles has probably increased business, because who wouldn’t want to help baby turtles cross the street!?

The Eastern painted turtle is not endangered – but they are precious to this community. And helping these baby turtles on their commute is something residents believe makes Middletown and Best Cleaners truly special.

Monday, October 16, 2023

The Hapeville Police received a call from a resident complaining about a young black boy in their neighborhood. When Officer Colleran arrived on the scene, he took time to get the full story. This entrepreneurial boy was going door to door advertising his lawn mowing business.

Officer Colleran said, “The young man was polite, respectful, and truthful.” Turns out the kid was saving up to buy a PlayStation – something the police officer was all about, as a gamer himself.

After sharing the story with his fellow officers, they all pitched in $500 to get the child a new PS5 and an annual subscription to the PlayStation gaming service. Officer Colleran also connected with the boy with his gamer tag so they could play together.

Friday, October 13, 2023

22-year-old Patrick Palepoi works as the fishing section manager in Sandy, Utah’s Scheels store. He loves talking about fishing – answering questions about fishing – if it’s about fishing, Patrick is your guy. So when a little boy named Xander showed interest at the store, the pair chatted for nearly half an hour.

Xander’s grandfather was an avid fisherman, but Xander hadn’t gone fishing since his grandfather passed away last year. Touched by his story, Patrick bought Xander a new fishing pole – and then worked with his mom to take the family on a fishing trip to a nearby reservoir. He even wrangled a couple of fishing pros to join the day on the water so they could pass on the legacy and knowledge to young Xander!

Xander got a once in a lifetime personal fishing experience – even snagging a big rainbow trout on the outing. It was an experience and a kindness that his family will never forget.

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by FOX 13 News (@fox13now)

Thursday, October 12, 2023

Summer Erdel is a military spouse who was traveling with two small children and even well practiced, great kids have their limits. For Summer’s girls, it was the third connecting flight. Thankfully, an angel was on this flight with them.

Jenny Martin was traveling solo, but saw Summer wrestling with her kids and luggage at check-in. As a mom of four, she was well aware of the special kind of stress Summer was dealing with. Jenny introduced herself and offered to help. She held Summer’s baby and helped check the stroller while boarding.

It was a Southwest flight, so Jenny chose to sit in front of the Erdel clan, letting Summer know that the noise and seat kicking wouldn’t bother her. Mid-flight, the baby projectile vomited all over Summer. Four times. Jenny calmly told the struggling mom that it was going to be ok. Then she took the baby (still covered in vomit) and rocked her to sleep so Summer could go to the lavatory and get cleaned off – Jenny even lent Summer a jacket.

After the flight, Jenny walked the family to baggage claim where Summer’s husband was waiting and then went on her way. The moms were able to reconnect over social media when Summer went looking for her guardian angel – sharing the story with the world.

Wednesday, October 11,  2023

The Pick of the Litter Thrift Shop in San Francisco exists to help fund the Peninsula Humane Society. And truly honest, good folks are working there behind the scenes. Oliver Jolis was busy sorting donated clothes for pricing and display – when he picked up a shirt and cash started pouring out on the table. Wrapped up in the clothes was $5000! Also in the bundle was a scrap of paper with car insurance information on it.

Oliver and his coworkers contacted the woman who had dropped off the clothes and were able to return the large sum of money. She was astounded by the honesty and incredibly grateful, as you can imagine.

Tuesday, October 10, 2023

Issy Spurway is a talented 20 year old. She uses her skills with a sewing machine and her savvy with TikTok to not only upcycle old clothes – but help keep memories alive. When Issy’s beloved grandfather passed away, she couldn’t bare the idea of throwing out his old clothes. They were memories. They were a comfort. But they were also taking up a lot of space.

So Issy got designing and began to alter her grandfather’s shirts into fashionable tops for herself. The Fashion School student uploaded her project on TikTok and of course, with her skillful designs and heartfelt purpose, the internet took her viral. This kept her busy during the pandemic and helped her through the grieving process.

Now Issy is helping others in a similar situation with tutorials on how to upcycle their own hand-me-downs.

Monday, October 9, 2023

Coffee is helping develop the economy of Mozambique all while reforesting the continent AND providing a haven for elephants, lions and hundreds of thousands of citizens!

The Gorongosa Coffee Project began in 2013 to reforest a 1500 square mile national park. It’s in central Mozambique, home to 200,000 people and many endangered animals. Combining coffee plant growth and other indigenous plants, the reforesting process is happening quickly – and the job creation of the coffee industry has poured money into central Mozambique!

In 2013 the Gorongosa Coffee Project was started by 10 families – now 1000 families work for the project, sending many children to schools and transforming the economy of Mozambique – and the model is now being used by neighboring countries as well!

Friday, October 6, 2023

We don’t deserve dogs. They provide love, without expecting a thing in return. Maybe they are a kind of angel. Certainly Scout is. Scout is a big black mutt who decided to escape the kennel at the Antrim County Animal Control, climb over multiple fences and cross a highway to take up residence at Meadow Brook Medical Care Facility.

The Sheriff was called multiple times by the old folks home to come pick Scout up. He just kept making his way back. And so the staff and residents decided to make it official and adopt the pup!

Scout fits right into his new home, brightening up the facility with a friendly disposition and a habit of falling asleep on a couch in the main lobby. Scout was even voted “Resident of the Month.”

Thursday, October 5, 2023

The post-pandemic office landscape is a little bit different. While many have returned to regular office hours, many businesses have seen their cultures completely transformed with less office space needed. That means in the BIG cities, there is a lot of unused real estate in great centralized locations.

Arlington, VA sits just outside of Washington D.C. and they have gotten innovative with some of their newly emptied office spaces. Area 2 Farms is transforming old office buildings into vertical indoor farms – which both fills the space and provides fresh local produce to the inner city space of Washington D.C.! They even office a monthly subscription to local residents who get boxes of fresh, organic produce delivered right to their homes.

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by Area 2 Farms (@area2farms)

Wednesday, October 4, 2023

While Southeast Louisiana has been in a drought for months – other parts of the country have experienced other kinds of extreme weather. SoCal got a hurricane and mudslides, and New England saw crazy flooding. This is going to sound wild to us, in our current state of insurance drama – but a 175 year insurance company did some major good in the state of Vermont!

The National Life Insurance Company lives by the moto “Believe in tomorrow. Do good today.” The Montpelier, VT company held their annual benefit concert called Do Good Fest. While it is usually a small affair in a sleepy New England town, this year national attention on New England floods led to record generosity!

With NLIC matching half a million dollars in donations, they raised over $1.5 million to help restore and rebuild flooded communities in Vermont. And that was just one event – The Vermont Flood Response & Recovery Fund has had close to $2.5 million donated this year.

Tuesday, October 3, 2023

No matter how prepared you think you are for an emergency, when one happens and the adrenaline hits, real heroes keep their cool and follow their training. Thankfully Shana Turnage, a school nurse at Franklinton Elementary knew exactly what to do when a scary situation hit the school.

The school custodian, Mr. Richard, was on the floor having a seizure. He was unresponsive, not breathing and had no heartbeat. Nurse Turnage immediately began CPR and instructed other staff members to call 911 and grab the school’s AED (Automated External Defibrillator).

First responders arrived shortly, but by then Nurse Turnage had already saved Mr. Richard’s life. He woke up in a hospital room surrounded by cards from kids at the school and hopes to get back to work soon. His coworkers also can’t wait to see their “ray of sunshine” back in the school halls.

 

Monday, October 2, 2023

Demario Davis is a beast on the football field. But more importantly, the linebacker is also a Man of God. (He literally got fined for wearing his Man of God headband as a part of his Saints uniform.) After a Saints win a couple weeks back, Demario was in the press booth and took his time sharing about how much God loves each and every one of us.

He also shared how Jesus healed his little 4 year old girl who had suffered an epileptic seizure just days before the game. Davis and his wife prayed in the ambulance and the hospital and their daughter had an immediate and complete recovery – something doctors didn’t understand because the recovery from such a seizure usually takes days.

Demario Davis wrapped up his time with the press promising to talk football in the future, but for that moment, he wanted everyone to “listen for the knock and let the Lord in.”

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by New Orleans Saints (@saints)

Friday, September 29, 2023

Mary Ruth is feeling the love at her job in a Kentucky Walmart! 86 year old Mary Ruth always has a smile and a hug if you’re willing for folks browsing at the Carrollton, Kentucky Walmart. But her journey to this calling came from a sad time in her life.

Mary Ruth is grateful for the lifetime of love she had with her husband Jacky. But after a five year battle with Parkinson’s, Jacky went to be with Jesus. Mary Ruth knew that the loneliness would destroy her if she wallowed, so she went to Walmart and got a job.

Turns out, a whole new life was waiting for the outgoing sweet lady. She is a magnet for kindness – pulling smiles out of everyone she greets. She has connected with special needs shoppers and often gets stopped for selfies because she’s become a bit of a celebrity. She shines bright and shares love, even through a time of grief.

Thursday, September 28, 2023

Eric Kilburn Jr. is a gentle giant in the classroom, and a monster on his high school football team. The 15 year old defensive end is already 6 foot 10, with feet even bigger than Shaquille O’Neal. In fact, that was a big problem – his mom was spending thousands of dollars on special-made shoes so her son could play football and even just walk to class without blisters.

A friend set up a fundraiser to help with the cost of shoes and the story went viral. That’s when shoe company Puma and athletic wear company Under Armour stepped in. They measured the giant high schooler and produced 4 pairs of cleats and 2 pairs of tennis shoes as a special gift to the student athlete!

And of course, word got to Shaq that there were some bigger feet than his, so he sent his personal tailor to the Kilburn’s house to fit the teen for custom suits for prom and homecoming! The family felt so blessed they started a Facebook Group called The Big Shoe Network to connect other families with help to get properly fitted shoes to their exceptional teenagers.

Wednesday, September 27, 2023

The mythical phoenix is famous for being reborn through the fire. Phoenix Bigler is no myth, but in many ways his story is far more incredible. The Covington teenager was just casually riding his bike when he had a heart attack that left him dead on the street. He lay there for 20 minutes with no oxygen to his brain. Fire fighters refused to stop resuscitation efforts and miraculously Phoenix responded.

The teenager was in a coma, unresponsive for days. His parents and community believed God would do a miracle and He surely did. Phoenix woke up! He is in rehab and will be for a very long time. Doctors believe Phoenix is 100% still in there, but his body has to relearn how to move and communicate.

Before the heart attack, Phoenix played saxophone at St. Paul High School. The other day his marching bandmates showed up to serenade him, his family and the staff at the hospital. They even paused to spend time thanking God for rescuing their friend and praying for Phoenix and his family. Miracles still happen. They happen all around the world and even around the corner on the northshore.

 

Tuesday, September 26, 2023

Competitive swimmer Merle Liivand is passionate about two big things: teaching the next generation the joys of swimming, and also, cleaning up the planet’s waterways. The Estonian native holds multiple world records because she swims with a monofin. It’s not uncommon for passersby to think they just saw a mermaid!

Recently Merle set a Guinness Record by swimming the circumference of Biscayne Bay in Miami – over thirty-one miles! It took her 14 hours, but that was because she wasn’t just swimming, she was collecting garbage and filling bags for her team to collect. She pulled 35 pounds of trash out of the bay that day.

 

Monday, September 25, 2023

Earlier this year Lahaina, Hawaii suffered devastating fires. Homes, cars, entire towns were swallowed whole by the fires. A family in Seattle watched the news, devastated. They had recently been on a family vacation to Hawaii and the destruction was heartbreaking.

Five-year-old Edison took his sadness and turned it into hope with a lemonade stand to send proceeds to the community of Lahaina. He set up on a hot Summer day and was overwhelmed with the community response. Neighbors often paid way more than $1 for their cup of lemonade. On top of generous tips, Edison’s parents’ jobs said they would match Edison’s sales with contributions to the cause.

After one week of selling lemonade, collecting donations, and corporate matches, Edison was able to send $17,000 to Hawaii to help rebuild. That’s some God math there. And some generous hearts, which we know a thing or two about here at LifeSongs.

Monday, September 11, 2023

It’s incredible, considering we live in one of the wealthiest countries in the History of the world – but every day millions of American children are food insecure. They don’t know if or when their next meal is going to come. And for many, the only meals they can count on come at their public school.

14-year-old DeJuan Strickland remembers that feeling of hunger and worry. Back when he was in 4th grade, his family was in a rough place and the food he could count on came from school. Wanting to make sure no other kid in his elementary school had to worry about whether they could have lunch, DeJuan launched a fundraiser to completely pay off the lunch debt for every student.

What started out as a goal to raise $200 has now turned into a positive fund of $6000 to pay for future students! Taking a willing heart and turning it into enough for many sure sounds a lot like what Jesus does. Something we are praying God does with your generous support during the LifeSongs Fall Shareathon, beginning Wednesday!

Friday, September 8, 2023

Jason Aussin was out playing golf with his father, Tony, and grandfather, Jose, on July 24. His grandpa had a great shot onto the green. They thought he was celebrating, but upon closer examination, he collapsed and started turning purple. Checked his breathing, checked for a pulse, nothing.

Without a moment’s hesitation, Jason sprung into action. He learned CPR while training to be a lifeguard just a couple of months ago and put his skills to good use. “Immediately, I knew what to do. I turned to my father and said, ‘Hey I need you on breaths. I’ll do the CPR’,” he told the news station. Jose can’t say enough about his son and grandson. “It’s like they’re professional doctors. They saved my life!” he said.

Jason is now encouraging others to learn CPR. You never know when you could become someone’s hero!

How’d you spend YOUR summer vacation? Maybe it wasn’t through CPR, but you HAVE had a positive impact on the lives of others – just by supporting the ministry of LifeSongs! Thank you!

Thursday, September 7, 2023

It was the hottest Summer on record for the Northern Hemisphere this year. Literally. Sweltering heat all across North America left many in need of air conditioning repair. Peggy Moore of Kansas City thought she was on top of it by getting her AC work done back in February.

Peggy paid an HVAC contractor $5000 in February to make sure her AC was operating for Summer. The 75 year old was being proactive. The problem is, by late May it was 90 degrees in her house. She couldn’t breathe!

Peggy couldn’t get the contractor back to her house, so she contacted a local news team to get her justice. The contractor finally showed up and installed a new air conditioner – but her house was still sweltering. Another contractor, Harry Frame, was following the story on the local news channel and offered to come take a look.

It turns out, the AC unit pushed by the first contractor was way too small for Peggy’s house. In an act of extraordinary generosity – given the super hot Summer and guaranteed sales in the air conditioning business – Harry installed a new, properly sized unit so Ms. Peggy could live in comfort and safety.

Whew! We know just how important a working AC is! And we also know how wonderful it is to have your needs met through the kind generosity of others. It’s how we feel on a daily basis! Thank you for supporting the ministry of LifeSongs!

Wednesday, September 6, 2023

Ronnie was 13-years-old when he lost both of his parents. Dr. James Wittig had given his life to his career, but always wanted a son. Through a God orchestrated series of overlapping friendships, the pair were connected into a new family.

Dr. Wittig had long been praying for a chance to have a family. A former patient of his knew of a boy who had lost both parents in a matter of months. 13-year-old Ronnie was described as “adorable, kind, caring, energetic [and] very loving.” The lifelong bachelor and the orphan bonded immediately and the good doctor went on to raise Ronnie as his son.

We’re grateful God has chosen us and called us His children. And we know how incredible it is to be part of a loving family, even if it’s not by birth. Thank you for being part of the LifeSongs family through your giving, and thank you for inviting even more people to join by sharing God’s love everyday!

Tuesday, September 5, 2023

In rural Ghana, the nearest hospital could be hours away. That means even treatable conditions become a matter of life and death. Osei Boateng (pronounced: Oh-say Boa-tang) grew up in one such rural village and felt a strong call to help. After studying biology at Cornell University and earning a master’s in Healthcare Administration, he started looking for a flexible way to tackle the problem.

Boateng started the nonprofit, OKB Hope Foundation, and in 2021, he converted a van into a mobile doctor’s office to bring health care directly to those in need. A few times a week, the mobile clinic and a medical team travel to remote communities, running basic labs, doing bloodwork and providing medications the rest of the developed world takes for granted.

Since its launch, the Hope Health Van has served more than 4,000 Ghanaians across more than 45 rural communities. Dozens of volunteers now serve as clinicians and the hope is to convert two more vans soon, to reach thousands more – even expanding into other Sub-Saharan countries.

 

Have you ever felt a strong call to help? We know that to be true, based on the amazing response to the needs of LifeSongs – THANK YOU so much!

Monday, September 4, 2023

It’s a lot easier to cheer on golf when you know it means help for those hurting in Hawaii! Golf champion Collin Morikawa committed $1000 for every birdie he made across three FedEx Cup Playoff events. For Morikawa, it’s about taking care of the people who welcomed his family to America.

Collin Morikawa was born and raised in California, but his family originally immigrated from Japan to Maui. And the golf fans of Hawaii are pleased to note that Morikawa is on a hot streak – having counted six birdies in the first of three events.

The donated funds will be spread between United Way and World Central Kitchen – helping families both rebuild and feeding them at their point of need right now.

We know all too well the struggles that come with rebuilding after a disaster, and we also know the feeling of so many selfless strangers stepping in to help. We’re continuing to pray for the people of Hawaii (Maui), and expressing our gratitude to YOU for your generosity.

Friday, September 1, 2023

Barbara Lakin, a former fashion designer in New York City, spends a lot of time playing with dolls. She sews them tiny new dresses, dyes and styles their hair and generally gives worn-out old Barbies a new life. However, these dolls serve a bigger purpose: Lakin is a volunteer with Team TLC NYC, an organization that meets migrants upon their arrival in the city and provides them with necessities and other forms of aid.

In March, the organization opened the Little Shop of Kindness, where immigrants and refugees can shop for free and young girls can receive the Barbies that Lakin so lovingly refurbishes. Barbara also does her best to source Barbies and dolls besides the stereotypical blondes, so the children from all over the world get dolls that look more like them.

It’s a small gesture, but Barbara says seeing children receive their own little piece of hope in the midst of so much change makes a big difference.

What helps provide hope in the midst of change in your life? LifeSongs is able to anchor you to the hope we have in Jesus every day, and that’s possible because of YOUR support. Thank you so much!

Thursday, August 31, 2023

Zack Conti loves football. He’s a walk-on Offensive Lineman for Eastern Michigan University. Zack has spent years of college going from class, to football practice to odd jobs to pay for it all. He’s worked in landscaping, demo, even selling his blood plasma to be able to stay in school and play ball. Then there’s the added stress of his mom needing a kidney donor back home.

Zack is a hard worker, and quiet. He didn’t raise a fuss, complain or even ask for help – but his friends on the team saw his struggle. Brian Dooley, a fellow lineman went to their coach and asked for help transferring his scholarship to Zack. They worked with the University and got it all sorted out. Now Zack has a full ride for the rest of his undergraduate degree – and for grad school too!

Both lineman will play tomorrow night against Howard University in the season opener for the Eastern Michigan Eagles.

Stories like these remind us of the power of hard work, determination and teamwork. We’re so grateful to those who give to support the ministry of LifeSongs. It helps our team grow and helps us know we can lean on each other when we need that support. Thank you for being part of this team!

Wednesday, August 30, 2023

When Sharaine and Wilson Caraballo moved into their new home, they were nervous about how their family would be received; a big family of seven – also, the only Black family in the Pawtucket, Rhode Island neighborhood. But the very first day in their home, their 82-year-old neighbor from across the street showed up with his ladder to welcome them to the street and help with some minor repairs.

Paul Callahan is the neighborhood handyman, and has become like a grandfather to the Caraballo children. He spends every day at their house, playing with the kids and sharing his life story. He’s at every family cook-out and holiday. He is no longer a neighbor, he’s family.

Turns out the big loving Caraballo family was just what Paul needed, after losing his wife earlier in the year. Now he’s got 5 grandkids to play with each day. Also, since Paul is a handyman, Caraballo dad Wilson can kick back and relax in his new home!

 

What makes YOU feel like part of a family? We are so grateful we get to call you part of the LifeSongs family – and your support keeps this ministry going, inviting even more people to join in and become part of this community. Thank you!

Tuesday, August 29, 2023

According to the non-profit “No Kid Hungry,” more than 12 million children in the U.S. live in “food insecure” homes and that’s exactly why “Blessings in a Backpack” was born.  They first started in 2013 when they gave backpacks full of food to 42 kids in three schools. Along with the food, they also include handwritten notes inside each bag. At one school that is benefitting from the program in Atlanta, they’re seeing a 100% attendance rate.

Melissa Archer, a spokesperson for Blessings in a Backpack said, “From what we’ve heard from the kids, they say that when they get something like this, that it comes from people that don’t even know them, that it shows them that the community out there cares about them, even though they don’t know who we are.”

Thank YOU for showing that our community is cared for, too, through your support for LifeSongs. We’re so grateful for you!

Monday, August 28, 2023

When Gary Benitez was 14, he was nearly killed by a falling tree. He and some friends were playing wiffle ball when the rotted branch knocked him unconscious. He woke up two days later in the hospital with no clue what had happened.

Sixteen years passed. Gary grew up and became a first responder at his local fire department. He wanted to help save lives, just like the fire fighters who saved him as a teenager. With the help of a local news team, Gary was able to finally meet the men who saved his life.

It was a very emotional moment when Gary got to share how he now saves lives because they first saved him.

You may never meet the people whose lives you’ve been a part of, but you are part of the stories of so many in our community. Your support for LifeSongs helps remind SELA of God’s love for them every single day. Thank you!

Friday, August 25, 2023

Alvin Irby is a first grade teacher who stopped by a barbershop in the Bronx to get a fresh cut for school. Before long he saw one of his students come into the shop as well.

Alvin watched as his first grader squirmed in boredom. He couldn’t help but think this would have been a great opportunity to practice his reading … but there were no books around. That moment inspired Alvin’s non-profit Barbershop Books.

Since 2013, Barbershop Books has placed more than 50,000 free children’s books in over 200 barber shops across the country! His hope is that young children (especially kids in underserved, poor communities) will discover that reading isn’t just a school assignment – there’s so much joy and adventure to be found!

Thursday, August 24, 2023

Colby is crazy about his neighborhood mailman, Mike!

We live in a time where so much gets delivered to us from our friendly mail carriers – and Mailman Mike loves getting to smile and chat with Colby every day. For his second birthday, Colby’s mom Jessica organized a parade of mail trucks, sprinkled in with the garbage truck and local police.

At the end of the parade, Mailman Mike pulled up and delivered a special present for Colby – his own toddler-sized custom painted mail carrier truck! Mike even presented Colby a certificate declaring him an honorary mail carrier in the state of Connecticut. And Jessica had a special Postal Worker uniform for her baby boy!

 

Wednesday, August 23, 2023

8-year-old Lyla Thomas loves growing up in Tulsa, OK. She loves her hometown and wants everyone in the community to be able to have fun. She was at a parade with her family and saw a homeless person. This sparked an idea for the compassionate little girl. Her program is called Fair Share.

Lyla is working to raise thousands of dollars with the help of other kids and social services. The program connects unhoused individuals with a case worker, who takes them out for a night at the state fair, providing food, a bag of hygiene supplies (packed by the kids) and the opportunity to see the various services available to them.

Lyla and her friends not only want to see everyone enjoy the state fair, but to feel loved and reminded that they are not alone – there is hope and help.

Tuesday, August 22, 2023

Chris Lane is a country music super star – but he hopped on Instagram to share a lovely story with his fans, that has nothing to do with honkey or tonk. He just wanted to brag about his sweet wife, Lauren.

Chris and Lauren got married in 2019 and have two young sons. Chris shared that as he was climbing into bed he saw his wife was on her Amazon app. But she wasn’t shopping for herself. Lauren was pulling up teachers’ amazon wishlists and buying their entire lists for them!

Chris said of his wife Lauren, “I’m not surprised because I feel like she’s constantly always trying to help somebody. She just has the sweetest soul, sweetest heart, and I just feel like the luckiest man in the world that I like was able to marry such a sweet soul.”

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by Chris Lane (@iamchrislane)

Monday, August 21, 2023

A 12 year old in North Dakota spent his Summer not chilling by the pool or playing Fortnite with his peers – but working hard to improve the lives of the heroes in his community.

Alex Lattergrass has been mowing lawns to make money for years – but this Summer he launched a 50 Yard Challenge as a way to say thanks to law enforcement officers, firefighters, emergency medical responders and military families. His mowing, hedging and weeding skills are impeccable – as displayed on yards across his community.

Alex’s dad works for the Fargo Police Department, so he knows how busy they are serving and protecting. This was his way of taking care of their families, while they are busy taking care of the whole community.

 

Friday, August 18, 2023

Being a politician has got to be stressful. Every move you make is criticized. Everything you say can be misconstrued or used against you. Good thing our Louisiana State Representatives can blow off some steam in a healthy, fun way!

About 40 state reps played in a charity basketball game on the hardwoods of LSU’s Pete Maravich Assembly Center. The Senate beat the House of Representatives 32-31. Not exactly a blow out.

After the game, a drawing was held to see which district would get a fully refurbished basketball court, funded by the Pelicans. Keller Center on Magnolia Street in Central City was the big winner! The work was done quickly and kids were able to hoop it up before school started back.

 

Thursday, August 17, 2023

In 2008 Stacey Buckner had a stroke that left her with traumatic brain injuries. She nearly died. The long road of therapy to get back the ability to talk and her fine motor skills was difficult to say the least. But that work led to a job working for the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Fayetteville, VA.

Stacey’s post recovery job involved connecting with veterans about their medical appointments. She made friends fast. And she also learned about the problems these new veteran friends faced – many of them homeless. This inspired Stacey to launch the Off-Road Outreach program.

Stacey rigged up her Jeep with a mobile shower, laundry machines and a cook station. She takes the off-road full service vehicle to meet up with the homeless veterans and gives them company while they take care of themselves. Because of her connection with the V.A., she’s also able to get these homeless veterans plugged into social services available to them. So far, Stacey’s Off-Road Outreach has helped over 1,000 homeless veterans!

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by OFF-ROAD OUTREACH (@offroadoutreach)

Wednesday, August 16, 2023

Kristi Hadfield’s official title is “paramedic” but she might need to change it to “Guardian Angel.” Six years ago, Kristi was in the ambulance that responded to a heart attack call. John Cunningham’s heart had stopped, but Kristi performed chest compressions all the way to the hospital where he was jolted back to life.

Kristi Facebook-friended John’s family (something she often does with patients), including his daughter Molly Jones. Flash forward six years later and this time Molly was in need of medical care. She was placed on the kidney transplant list.

Kristi messaged Molly, “Listen kid, I saved your dad and I’m going to save you too!” A few months later and a successful surgery later, the families are now forever linked.

Tuesday, August 15, 2023

The power that TikTokers wield is truly impressive – especially when they use it for good. Jerrad posts under the name @internetfamouslol. One day he was out grocery shopping and saw a local author with a table set up to sign his debut novel.

The author is Shawn Warner. The former software engineer and Army veteran had put everything into his adventure book “Leigh Howard and The Ghosts of Simmons-Pierce Manor.” The path to being a successful writer is filled with challenges – like having a book signing in a grocery store.

When Jerrad first saw Shawn Warner, the author looked pretty bummed. But with a little TikTok love, and a few hours of internet magic, Warner’s book shot up to the top of Amazon’s bestseller’s list!

Monday, August 14, 2023

Grandpa Reads the Comics is a YouTube channel for anyone who could use a little more happy grandfather in their lives. During the pandemic, Grandpa Reads the Comics was started to connect with family. Grandpa reads the funnies, and occasionally fiddles with the banjo, ukulele and piano.

Not too long ago, Grandpa Reads the Comics had around 200 subscribers and his videos only got a couple views, mostly his actual grandkids. That’s when Cole Caetano discovered the channel. Cole is a king maker in social media, connecting his large audience to worthy channels. He put the word out about this adorable channel and well … things have changed.

Now Grandpa has half a million subs and is filling the internet with wholesome kindness. Grandpa says he’d put Cole Caetano on the Mt. Rushmore of his life for his kindness. Cole was just happy to help get a little more kindness out in the world.

@karvetv Grandpa Reads the Comics❤️ #wholesome #grandpa #comic ♬ Married Life (From “Up”) – Sergy el Som

 

Friday, August 11, 2023

Mom, Siobhan and daughter-Indie were browsing at the shopping mall. Indie was looking at the Apple store and some make-up. Looking good, helps her feel good – which is imperative because Indie is on her fifth round of chemotherapy.

While at the Apple store a man walked up to the mom and daughter, telling Siobhan his son had cancer and he knows exactly how they feel. His son is now 10 years into remission and he wanted to encourage young Indie as she battles it out. Then he gave the girl a £100 note.

Indie burst out, “Mummy I’m rich!” and the pair cried for joy there in the middle of the Apple store. Indie spent her gift on some make-up which she uses for video tutorials on social media – a way to encourage other girls going through chemotherapy.

Thursday, August 10, 2023

A firefighter and his wife in Ocala, FL had been praying for a decade to have a child. And God answered their prayers.

In Florida, many fire stations are equipped with Safe Haven Baby Boxes. This is a small door on the building where new parents can safely and anonymously surrender their newborns if they are unable to care for them. When the alarm went off in the middle of the night, the firefighter expected it to be a false alarm, but there in the Safe Haven Baby Box was a tiny baby girl, wrapped up in a snuggly blanket.

The firefighter said that when he locked eyes with the infant, it was pure love at first sight. At the hospital, he left a note with social services letting them know about his desire to adopt the little girl – he and his wife were already registered to adopt. Two days later, that baby girl became their daughter, Zoe.

Wednesday, August 9, 2023

Cragun Foulger’s bucket-list ambition was to complete a 45 mile hike along the west coast of Vancouver Island. The West Coast Trail is an iconic backpacking trail for elite hikers. And Cragun was ready to take it on. However when he landed in Vancouver, his luggage did not.

All of his hiking gear – missing. Cragun blitzed through the stages of grief that he would not be able to make the hike and posted about the situation to his friends on social media. His hiking buddies, however, had his back.

Nearly twenty folks donated clothes and equipment, like a backpack, tent and other equipment needed for the long West Coast Trail hike. Not only did Cragun get to check off a major bucket-list dream, he made a bunch of new friends on a once in a lifetime adventure!

Tuesday, August 8, 2023

Labrador Retrievers have been one of the most popular dog breeds in America for YEARS! They are loyal and fun and great with kids. But they need a lot of exercise, which is why Kelly Mason takes her 4 year old golden lab Daisy for a long walk every day in their local park.

One of Daisy’s favorite things to do is sniff out and retrieve long lost frisbees. These discs are often lost and abandoned along the Frisbee Golf course in Grand Vue Park. So far Daisy has retrieved 155 lost discs!

Grand Vue Park is always grateful when Daisy and Kelly drop off the sports equipment and recently launched Daisy’s Discs – a program to sell the recovered frisbees as a fundraiser for park maintenance! Of course, if the disc has someone’s name on it, they return it free of charge, but most end up donating to Daisy’s Discs anyway.

Monday, August 7, 2023

Have you ever locked yourself out of the house? It happens. And it happened to 78 year old Nancy Reburn not too long ago. Nancy is pretty feisty and decided to try and break into her own home by climbing through a window. Unfortunately for Nancy, her two hip replacements weren’t rated for breaking and entering.

Nancy was stuck for five long hours. She cried out in prayer and yelled for help with every breath. Jose Sanchez was delivering newspapers down the road and heard Nancy’s cry for help. He rushed to her side and called 9-1-1 for assistance.

Jose is now considered the neighborhood’s guardian angel!

Friday, August 4, 2023

The numerical expression of the sentence “I love you” is 143. One letter, four letters, three letters. Mr. Rogers popularized using the number 143 to sneak in I love you’s. And Mr. Rogers is a personal hero of Kevin Bonecutter, who is taking 143 to the next level.

Kevin started on June 1st with a mission to do 143 acts of kindness in just 40 days. And his hometown of Cincinnati has been watching in awe. Kevin has cut grass at vacant homes, picked up trash in the community and handed out free food to anyone in need. He’s raised money for pediatric brain cancer research and even helped an elderly man cross the street in a driving rain.

Through all of the acts of kindness, Kevin has made new friends and inspired others to pay it forward. Just one man – saying “I love you” and changing his world!

 

Thursday, August 3, 2023

Oliver turned 8 this Summer. While he didn’t have many friends to invite over for a birthday party – he had one of the wildest, coolest birthdays a little boy could have. Oliver’s grandfather and uncle are both truck drivers, and he’s been obsessed with big trucks since he was a toddler. He has a subscription to a trucker’s magazine and already knows what he wants to do when he grows up!

Oliver’s mom Katherine took to Facebook to see if any local truck drivers would come give Oliver a ride for his birthday. But the trucking community knew they could do even better than a ride around the block. Local truckers put together a 40 truck convoy! Dozens of truck drivers came in for the parade of trucks – at great expense – to rally around Oliver.

 

Wednesday, August 2, 2023

James Porter has that all-American entrepreneurial spirit. He runs a small lawn maintenance business in upstate New York. Also, James is legally blind. Since he can’t drive, he pulls his lawn equipment in a hand-pulled trailer to his job sites. Things were going well until his trailer broke.

Paul Koenig so greatly admires James enthusiasm for his work that he stepped in and not only bought James a new hand-pulled trailer, but also a new lawn mower as an investment in the local business. Of course James was incredibly grateful – not only for the gift of equipment, but for Paul’s five-star rating on Facebook where he has been recruiting new business for the blind entrepreneur.

Tuesday, August 1, 2023

11 year-old Zac worked hard to earn his e-bike. He helped launch a clothing business with his mom, building the website, designing the company logo and working the stall at local markets on weekends. Not to mention the little entrepreneur donates 10% of his profits to a local children’s charity. And all the hard work paid off when Zac finally saved enough and got his new bike in January. Then, in June, the family’s apartment was broken into and his bike was stolen.

Knowing how hard Zac worked to buy his bike, a friend of the family started a GoFundMe campaign to help raise funds to replace it. So far, $3,115 has been raised of the $3,300 target. Zac’s mom said she’s been blown away by the “community spirit” and something tells me little Zac will be back on a new bike very soon.

Monday, July 31, 2023

Just a couple of weeks ago, Demario Davis, All-Pro Linebacker and the New Orleans Saints captain held the first graduation ceremony for his Devoted Dreamers Academy mentorship program for 8th through 12th-grade students.

Demario and his wife, Tamela, founded the Devoted Dreamers Academy in 2013 and have provided the next generation of leaders with a decade of tools to be successful spiritually, mentally, and physically. Students receive everything from college prep resources to interacting in sports business labs, ensuring they are well-prepared for life after grade school.

This is the kind of Jesus-behavior we’ve come to expect from the Saints own Man Of God. For more information, check out Devoted Dreamers Academy.

Friday, July 28, 2023

Unfortunately life as a veteran can be quite challenging. 78 year old Navy veteran Judith McElven found herself in dire straits. Her partner had passed, she was dealing with Parkinson’s disease and could no longer make rent.

Diane, who lives across the hall in the apartment complex, went to check on Judith and could see she was overwhelmed. Judith said she could really use some help. So Diane took to social media and soon a group of strangers were taking good care of Ms. Judith.

A local realtor had some donated furniture. Another person paid to have Judith’s busted and ruined furniture hauled off. Others pitched in to clean, get her a new TV and cable, and most importantly let this Navy veteran know that she was not alone anymore.

Thursday, July 27, 2023

A great way to process big emotions is to write it all down – which is what fifteen students at High Achievers Student Enrichment Center in Houma did – and they had the entire collection published as a book.

Fifteen children, ranging from first to fourth grade, wrote about their experiences through Hurricane Ida. They share about being scared, watching their parents’ reactions and worrying about their pets and visiting family out of state.

Pamela Pellegrin, the school’s director, wanted to guide these children in processing their feelings. Many of the younger kids drew pictures for the book which can be read, but not checked out, at the Terrebonne Parish Library. And while the stories talk a lot about fear and sadness, many children shared about how people took good care of their families, building new houses and how the community came together like they had never seen before.

Wednesday, July 26, 2023

Marty and Myriam have a love story that spans over 30 years. And it all started with the rich smell of chocolate. Marty, an American from California, was visiting Brussels, Belgium. He poked his head into a local chocolate shop and fell instantly in love.

Myriam was working the counter that day at the Belgian chocolate shoppe. Marty flirted and bought some chocolate. And did the same the next day. And the day after that. Five days straight! Eventually Marty would return home to California, but the pair wrote letters back and forth for nearly a decade – falling deeply in love.

Finally Myriam moved across the pond and they married. Thirty years later they are more in love than ever. And it all started with a little chocolate shop in Brussels.

Tuesday, July 25, 2023

The police department in Greenville, SC decided to take a new approach in handling the growing homeless issue in their community – they began working with folks who wanted to reconnect with their families.

Mr. Bryant had been living on the streets for two whole years. That’s where Lt. Conroy found Mr. Bryant. With a little legwork, some Facebooking and phone calls – the police were able to find Mr. Bryant’s family, who were living a couple states to the north, in Virginia.

His family was so filled with joy that their prodigal had been found, they jumped in the car and drove down to South Carolina to pick Mr. Bryant up and bring him home.

Monday, July 24, 2023

The Jefferson Parish Library has launched an innovative program, “Beyond Books: Library of Things.” The Library of Things allows library cardholders access to temporary loans of practical and recreational objects, ranging from cookware, such as baking pans, cookie cutters, an Instant Pot and air fryer, to an Instax camera, sewing machine, tape measure and telescope.

The Library of Things concept is a growing trend in public libraries. The process is similar to checking out a book. Patrons are allowed to check out objects for a two-week period. Items must be returned to the same location as checkout. They will not travel between branch locations.

The ultimate goal is to include a collection at all 16 branches of the Jefferson Parish Library. All available objects will be displayed in catalogs at the hosting libraries and online at jplibrary.net.

Friday, July 21, 2023

Dr. Robert Moore of San Jose, CA was celebrating his 100th birthday. Friends, family, former colleagues and students all joined forces to give this doggy-loving retired dean from San Jose State. Over 200 dogs (along with their owners) showed up for an organized parade of pups to honor the centenarian!

Dr. Moore’s daughter Alison was expecting maybe 20 folks to show up. Instead, the parade wrapped around the block and down the street with hundreds in attendance! And Dr. Moore was thrilled – petting every single puppy that came by to wish him a happy 100th birthday.

 

Thursday, July 20, 2023

Industrial Tech teacher Rob Van Der Hagen runs his Minnesota shop class like a business and the students have risen to the expectations.

During the pandemic, Mr. Van Der Hagen closed his auto parts stores and decided to start a new career as a teacher. His innovation of shop class has students lined up to join. New senior Austin says “I feel like I’m getting prepared for a career!” And that’s sort of the goal of the class – to prepare teenagers to be treated like adults, with expectations on their decisions and performance.

To give some added pressure, Mr. Van Der Hagen’s class is actually serving the community – repairing and rebuilding a variety of vehicles like snowmobiles and four wheelers. Last year the class repaired over 100 vehicles!

Wednesday, July 19, 2023

Thirteen years after losing both his legs in war, Hari Budha Magar, a British Nepali Veteran, became the first double above-the-knee amputee to climb Mount Everest. Hari’s story is a true testimony and one of redemption.

After battling severe alcoholism and depression as a result of his experiences in war, he eventually channeled this pain and decided to climb Mt. Everest instead. Most Napali veterans have been banned from the feat, but Hari overcame this opposition and completed this incredible task with the help of some friends and several pairs of prosthetics.

Hari now says that he wants to return to the spot in Afghanistan where he lost his legs to say “thank you”. He says because if he still had his legs, he would have never climbed Mt. Everest.

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by Hari Budha Magar (@hari_budha_magar)

Tuesday, July 18, 2023

It’s a pretty big honor to be the valedictorian of a graduating class – but what about national honors? The US Secretary of Education published the 59th Class of US Presidential Scholars. This nationwide list of only 161 graduating high school seniors celebrates great academic accomplishments – and three Louisiana Seniors made the cut!

Daniel Liu out of Baton Rouge, Ananya in Shreveport and closer to home – Khalil McKnight of Hammond High! There are 3.7 million graduating seniors in America this year – only 5000 qualified as Presidential Scholars and only 161 received the honor! Very impressive.

Smart cookies in Louisiana – and don’t forget to sign up your school to be a prayer school of the day for the coming school year.

Monday, July 17, 2023

Mama Shu lost her 2 year old son to a hit and run in 2007. She thought the grief would end her – but she persevered for her family. Then in 2021 she lost another son, who was killed while participating in the neighborhood watch for their community.

Mama Shu said she had to “change grief into glory – pain into power.” But how do you turn that level of pain into something beautiful? For years Mama Shu has run Avalon Village – a nonprofit that is revitalizing her neighborhood by converting abandoned properties and green space into community buildings, parks and playgrounds.

Avalon Village now owns 45 lots across three city blocks. Their biggest success was converting an old home into The Homework House for afterschool resources. Helping kids with school is close to Mama Shu’s heart, because she spent nearly 30 years as an administrator at Highland Park public schools.

The Homework House went from abandoned eyesore to a community library with computers, a 3D printer, music studio kitchen and handicap accessible bathrooms!

Friday, July 14, 2023

Lenita Edge is a traffic control officer in Detroit. One day while on her job, she was interviewed by TikToker Zachery (@MDMotivator). And her interview gained the hearts of millions (like 9 million views worth of hearts). Lenita spoke about why she enjoys her profession directing traffic; she likes making sure that people are able to take care of responsibilities and stay safe while they do them. The recently widowed, single mother is also a huge Detroit Tigers fan.

Zachery asked Lenita if she wanted to attend a game with him, surprising her with $500 along with her tickets. Then the TikToker started a secret fundraising campaign for the single mom who protects so many.

At the Tigers game, Lenita was given a check for $50,000 from Tigers catcher, Jake Rogers!

@mdmotivator $50,000 for single mom 🥺❤️ #mother #baseball #detroit #kindness #money ♬ original sound – Zachery Dereniowski

Thursday, July 13, 2023

The Gift of Adoption is a nonprofit organization just achieved an incredible milestone – placing their 5000th child into a family! 11-year-old Josue from Ecuador was the 5000th child to be placed with a family as a result of the efforts of Gift of Adoption.

Nicole and David, Josue’s new parents were like many families who wanted to adopt but couldn’t due to the financial burden. The Gift of Adoption provides help in the form of grants to families so they can achieve their dream of adoption.

In addition to Josue being placed with a family, he was adopted along with his two biological brothers, Darwin, 9, and Abraham, 6. Their mom Nicole said, “We are so happy that we can provide a permanent home for these brothers, and they can now grow up together in a stable environment.”

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by Gift of Adoption Fund (@giftofadoption)

Wednesday, July 12, 2023

Rehan Staton was always more into physical activity than school work. His grades were terrible, but he was winning martial arts and boxing competitions left and right. After high school Rehan couldn’t get into any colleges and an injury ended his fighting career. This led to a job as a sanitation worker, so he could provide for his father who had a stroke and was out of work.

It was in this job as a garbage man that Rehan found “his people.” A group of men invested in Rehan, encouraged him and helped him believe in himself. Rehan managed to enroll at Bowie State University and saw his grades hold steady at a perfect 4.0. He then transferred to Maryland State and then on to Harvard!

His story garnered attention at NBC News – and then Tyler Perry stepped in to cover Rehan’s tuition. Wanting to give back, after so much was given to him, Rehan began a nonprofit to encourage other sanitation workers at universities around the country, thanking them for their hard work and giving them the respect they deserve.

Tuesday, July 11, 2023

The crowd shouted in fear – the firefighters tried to wave him off – but a Colombian man was determined to save more than 2 dozen puppies from a fire.

The blaze happened at an apartment building in Lima, Peru. Sebastian Arias scaled the building up to the third floor, busted out a window and rescued 25 puppies who were trapped upstairs. Others from the building used mattresses and sheets below to catch the puppies as Sebastian lowered them down.

The hero said he wasn’t sure how he managed to climb the building – it was just pure adrenaline, but he hoped that someone would rescue his dog in a similar situation.

🔴 AHORA: Sebastián Arias, joven colombiano, rescató a 25 perros que se encontraban atrapados en el techo de un edificio en Gamarra durante un voraz incendio esta tarde.#UltimaHora #Urgente #Ahora #LoUltimo #Peru #Lima #Incendio pic.twitter.com/6H57yFAHzW

— Alerta News Perú (@AlertaNewsPeru) June 10, 2023

 

Monday, July 10, 2023

When Stephanie Peach shopped at her local Pick and Save she was always excited to see a store clerk there, named Dennis Raitan. During one of their encounters, Dennis mentioned that he hoped that the weather would stay warm because he didn’t have a functioning boiler. Dennis’ boiler had been out for over a year and he had no heat or hot water.

After hearing this, Stephanie was propelled into action and decided to start a GoFundMe for Dennis. Stephanie said, “No 65-year old should have to take cold showers and not have heat.” In just a few weeks, Stephanie’s GoFundMe had raised $5,000 for Dennis’ new boiler and even a new A/C too for the summer months.

Dennis said of Stephanie, “I’m just flabbergasted. I guess she’s one of the few people that leaves me speechless. So, she did that.”

Friday, July 7, 2023

When the Perceful family moved to a new town in Oklahoma, their daughter Magnolia had just one big request – to get her swing hung on the tree in front of the house. But the trees at the Perceful’s new place were BIG and they didn’t have a ladder nearly tall enough to accomplish the task. Mom-Meaghan posted on their community Facebook page looking for help – and help soon arrived, in a flashy red truck.

The local fire department was very happy to help hang the swing for Magnolia and welcome the Perceful family to the hood. Meghan said the looks on all of her children’s faces (Magnolia, Marin, Colt and Kinsley) was “priceless.” Each child got their own plastic firefighter helmet as well.

One of the firefighters, Ariel Shepherd, was the department’s first female firefighter and she was excited to show Magnolia, Marin and Kinsley that they could grow up to be one too!

Thursday, July 6, 2023

Shaquille O’Neal is known for a lot of things, and no, one of them is not his 90s Shaq Diesel album. He is a Hall-of-Fame basketball player and a BIG man, with an even bigger heart. Shaq has said, ‘”My favorite thing to do is when I’m in Best Buy, Walmart, if I see a kid, get them something that I see he’s looking at.”

He recently put this generosity on display when he bought a washer and dryer for customers at Home Depot. The ladies were totally shocked by the surprise act of kindness from the athlete while they were on what seemed like a regular shopping day.

This isn’t the first time Shaq has gifted items to his fans. He has bought scooters for kids, vans for families, and even an engagement ring for a stranger!

Shaq went to Home Depot and bought this family a washer and dryer 💪 pic.twitter.com/m86MSnWQu8

— NBACentral (@TheNBACentral) June 14, 2023

Wednesday, July 5, 2023

Jamie West has had a hard go of it. Both her parents were addicts and from a very early age, she struggled with bouts of homelessness and eventually in-and-out of the foster care system. Jamie spent a large portion of her adolescence hitchhiking. One day after being hungry for a week, Jamie wandered into a White Castle. Upon seeing Jamie, an employee allowed Jamie to not only wash-up in the bathroom, but also gave her 3 days worth of food.

Eventually, Jamie’s aunt took her in and she no longer had to live on the streets. But she never forgot the kindness of the White Castle employee and every time she saw one it reminded her that it was a safe place. When it was time to get married to her future husband Andrew Schmidt, where else would she choose to get hitched but a White Castle restaurant! And if you get married in any kind of castle (even a White Castle), you have to dress the part. Jamie donned a ballgown and her groom was dressed as a prince.

Although she hasn’t kept in touch with the kind employee who gifted her with grace and grubs, Jamie says if she did see her again, “I would hug her and just say, ‘Thank you for being the reason I exist right now, not knowing what you were doing and just feeding somebody because you’re a good human.'”

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by TODAY (@todayshow)

Tuesday, July 4, 2023

Finding a safe place to make a life after serving in the armed forces is a challenge both for our veterans here in the US – and for service members fighting in Ukraine. And that’s not just the human vets. Rambo is a 3 year old German shepherd who was a frontline soldier with the Ukrainian defense. He was injured during a rocket attack but was mercifully rescued with life saving surgery.

After eight months of recovery and multiple surgeries, Rambo is now serving as a police dog with the Budapest Metropolitan Police. Rambo has plenty of battle scars and interacts with kids and citizens to help teach them about understanding others who are differently abled.

 

Monday, July 3, 2023

Sam Kaplan became the first of his seven siblings to earn a bachelor’s degree this year. He got his degree in Cinema and Media Arts from Georgia Gwinnett College. And like most of the graduates, his mom was there to cheer him on as he crossed the stage in his cap and gown. The only difference is that his mom is 99 years old. And Sam is 72.

Sam has had a very full life, having run a cleaning service, a telemarketing company, working as a taxi driver and customer service. During the pandemic, at the age of 68, he decided to enroll in college! He said he was just listening to the radio in his car when he heard an ad to get a degree in script writing.

The father of five had to relearn many study skills, but particularly enjoyed getting to know his fellow students – most of whom are fifty years younger than him. (Sam’s Dad-game is strong) Sam enjoyed showing off pictures of his family and telling stories to his classmates – but more than that, he loved hearing what their dreams for the future were.

Friday, June 30, 2023

Kit Kat has partnered with the Trombone Shorty Foundation to celebrate New Orleans music for Black Music Month. The Trombone Shorty Foundation is a non-profit organization named for home-grown musician Troy “Trombone Shorty” Andrews. His foundation is focused on inspiring the next generation of musicians through a variety of art-centered opportunities including education and mentorship.

In addition to the special jazz-themed wrapper, Kit Kat has also created “Hear it from Here,” which is a series of documentary shorts where local artists discuss the impact of Black music in their community.

Thursday, June 29, 2023

Brandi Tuck was determined to become a high powered New York lawyer, while studying at the University of Florida 20 years ago. One Spring Break, her entire life trajectory changed. She couldn’t find friends to hit the beach with her, so she decided to rack up some extra credit by volunteering at a homeless shelter.

Brandi had never been in a homeless shelter before. She wasn’t exactly excited to travel to inner city Atlanta but once there, she was astounded. The women they were serving were just normal people. In fact, they reminded her of her own mom. Brandi played with the kids at the shelter and fell in love with each one of them.

Brandi nearly dropped out of college right then and there to devote herself to helping homeless families. Her friends convinced her to finish school first, but fresh out of college Brandi began a non-profit called Path Home in her hometown of Portland. Path Home focuses on helping families dealing with homelessness in a holistic, safe and welcoming facility, built in an old church space. They take up to 17 families at a time for up to six months, helping transition to permanent housing along with job placement.

Last year Path Home helped 360 families. Brandi says, “When I see families succeed, that’s all that I need to continue doing this work.”

Wednesday, June 28, 2023

Missouri 8th grade Xavier Jones chose to walk to his middle-school graduation after he missed couldn’t get a ride to the ceremony. How long and how far did Xavier go? Along with his brother and a friend, he walked 10,000 steps. That’s 6 miles, which took over 2 hours!

When Xavier arrived at the ceremony, his mentor, Darren Seals, who was speaking at the ceremony, had the crowd give Xavier a standing ovation. Not only did the young man get recognized by the entire audience in attendance, he caught the attention of a college president and Miami Dolphins football player Terron Armstead. Ironically, he was offered not only a free ride to college, complete with tuition and books, he also got an electric bike.

When asked what motivated him to walk all the way to his graduation, he recalled what his mentor, Mr. Seals told him, “If I want it, I got to go get it.”

Tuesday, June 27, 2023

Spencer founded SB Mowing company 11 years ago in Wichita, KS. He and his team now maintain about 40 properties each week. His success has provided opportunities to serve his community. For the last couple of years, whenever Spencer or his team are on a job and see a yard that is in obvious need of care – they knock on the door and offer their services for free.

SB Mowing makes cute videos of their helpful services – and currently have over a million subscribers on YouTube. Fans of the good work have sent in thousands of dollars to help fund the good deeds.

It might take a lot of time and effort, but Spencer has seen the gratitude of strangers who feel like they can be proud of their homes again.

 

Monday, June 26, 2023

It’s America’s pastime – catching a baseball game in the Summer. Whether it’s at a Major League Stadium, the College World Series or a local Little League game – just buy me some peanuts and cracker jacks already!

But what about when parents are not well-behaved at the ballfield? Parents are their kids’ biggest fans, which sometimes leads to confrontation with coaches and umpires with less than holy vocabulary and behavior. In Deptford, New Jersey, if you pick a fight with the Ump, you get stuck with the job!

The new rule this season only allows unruly parents back to the ballfield after they have served a sentence of playing umpire for three games. So maybe have a little compassion for the volunteer Little League umpires.

Friday, June 23, 2023

That Smoothie Place in Montgomery County Maryland is so much more than just a cold drink on a hot day. That Smoothie Place was founded by Monique Sotomarino to provide a safe haven for her sons, both with special needs.

The Sotomarinos offer jobs and internships for high schoolers with special needs. Sure, it might take a few extra minutes to get your smoothie, but you are providing incredible opportunities for these kids. And to make it fun for the whole family, Monique put games out at the waiting tables so you can put your phone away and spend some quality time together.

That Smoothie Place sounds like it isn’t just good for your health, but your heart! And it has been a big success, so much so that the family is looking to create franchise opportunities around the country to help other families provide special needs jobs in their communities.

Thursday, June 22, 2023

It all started with a Kindness Week Challenge from Brennan’s 8th grade teacher. Brennan’s way to embrace this challenge started by sending little gifts (especially chocolate) to an elder of his community, Ms. Ann. These tiny acts of kindness sparked a now almost 6 year friendship between the teen and 84 year old Ms. Ann.

They love to share stories of what’s going on in each other’s lives– Brennan talks with Ms. Ann about the day-to-day life of a teenager, while Ms. Ann loves to recount stories from when she grew up. Brennan’s mom says “The best thing a teenager can do is befriend someone elderly. I’m so glad our son has added more sunshine to her life.”

Wednesday, June 21, 2023

Jane Pearson is a hero. For 38 years Jane was a kindergarten teacher. Same school. Same classroom. Generations of students passing through her care. This year was her last, finally taking her retirement after a job well done.

I’m sure there was cake and a moment to honor her at the end of the school year commencement, but what might possibly mean even more to a 38 year kindergarten veteran?

One of her students reached out to Ms. Pearson’s daughter and they contacted some of her past students to surprise the retiring teacher. Jane’s daughter caught the reunion on camera. As you can imagine there were lots of happy tears.

 

Tuesday, June 20, 2023

Wildfires are raging across multiple portions of Canada. The East coast of the United States turned into an orange haze – erasing the iconic New York skyline as the smoke blew south. The fires are so out of control that other countries are sending in firefighters to help the Canadians.

One group of firefighters, from the South African organization Working on Fire just sent 200 troops into battle so to speak. South Africa understands the danger of wildfires and is one of the few countries that keeps a government funded full time firefighting force. They also have a longstanding relationship with Canada – the countries often support one another in times of crisis.

That’s beautiful. The US, Australia and New Zealand have also sent hundreds of firefighters to help Canada as well.

Monday, June 19, 2023

The legend of Dolly Parton continues to grow. The 12 time GRAMMY winning country singer is one of America’s greatest showpeople – and was recently inducted into the Rock N Roll Hall of Fame. She has a viral cake mix in grocery stores and a constantly out of stock custom strawberry pretzel pie ice cream from Jeni’s. But if you ask the country crooner what she wants to be known for, without hesitation she’ll point to her Imagination Library.

For decades Dolly Parton has sent HUNDREDS OF MILLIONS of books to kids for free to honor her father, who she says was so very smart, but never learned to read and it cost him dearly. Dolly Parton’s Imagination Library was founded in 1995 to inspire children to love reading. Recently the Imagination Library got a boost in funding from California who qualified every child in the state to receive a free book in the mail every month – with options in both English and Spanish.

Friday, June 16, 2023

When you write your essay for a college application, it’s important to really grab the readers’ attention. 18-year-old Aurora Sky Castner did just that with her application to Harvard. She wrote, “I was born in prison.”

And it’s true. Aurora’s mom gave birth to her in the Galveston County Jail. Her father picked her up from the medical ward and raised her as a single father. While her mom has not been a part of her life, many other men and women have raised her well. A mentorship program connected Aurora to Mona Hamby who in many ways has been her surrogate mom.

Aurora’s life maybe didn’t start out glamorous, but her future is bright! She’ll be starting at Harvard this fall with a full ride scholarship! She is planning on becoming a lawyer someday.

 

View this post on Instagram

 

A post shared by Good News Movement (@goodnews_movement)

 

Thursday, June 15, 2023

Sand is used to stop flood waters and rebuild wetlands and make family friendly beaches. And what is sand but very fine pieces of glass! Thus was born the Glass Half Full recycling program – the brainchild of Franziska Trautman while she was studying at Tulane for chemical engineering.

In just three years Trautman’s Glass Half Full organization has diverted 4 million pounds of glass from landfills and put the sand to good work protecting the coast. It’s been so successful that Glass Half Full has expanded to picking up not just in New Orleans, but Baton Rouge, commercial waste and soon will be expanding to the Mississippi coast as well!

Wednesday, June 14, 2023

Some are born heroes – others are forged in the fire. Jonathan McCray might be both. He was driving down Reverend Richard Wilson Dr. in Kenner when he noticed smoke pouring out of a home that also serves as a local in-home daycare.

Jonathan ran to the door and started banging. Once they were alerted to the flames, Jonathan helped evacuate the building – 15 people in total fled the flames with this local hero, including 10 children. Jonathan also managed to rescue three dogs in the dramatic events.

The Red Cross and community are helping the family as the damage is assessed and investigated.

Tuesday, June 13, 2023

The Hittle family took a trip to the Louisville Zoo – a much needed outing with their 3 month old baby, Judah.  When Judah’s big brother and Dad were checking out the orangutan enclosure, they saw one of the orange great apes pointing at Mom Dakota who was holding baby Judah at the moment. The orangutan (named Amber) wanted to see the baby closer!

The family posted a video of Dakota holding Judah down so the orangutan could coo and the newborn through the glass. That video has been liked over half a million times! The Louisville Zoo staff says Amber the Orangutan often taps on the glass to get folks attention when she wants to see them up close.

 

Monday, June 12, 2023

Joy Ryan and her grandson Brad have spent the last half decade racking up mileage on their quest to visit every US National Park. Grandma Joy’s Road Trip took six years to complete because there was that pesky COVID pandemic, but this year 93 year old Joy became the oldest person to accomplish the feat.

The Grandma and Grandson wrapped up their quest at the 63rd national park in American Samoa. Brad just loved the time he got with his grandma, saying “It was the greatest privilege of my life to be in the driver’s seat for Grandma Joy’s Road Trip.”

 

View this post on Instagram
